elements.content: A new 3D zinc-organic framework of [ZnL]·5H2O (1, K2L = potassium 4′-furyl-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine-4,4″-dicarboxylate) has been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 possesses a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected sra network with pores decorated by noncoordination furan rings, and it exhibits a broad blue luminescence emission band peaked at 450 nm. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2– ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn­(II), complex 1 exhibits a good thermal and acid-proof stability, and can be directly carbonized at 1000 °C under argon atmosphere into a new microporous carbon material C1000. The gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1a and microporous carbon C1000 have been studied by N2 and CO2 sorption measurements.

Complex 1 possesses a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected sra network with pores decorated by noncoordination furan rings, and it exhibits a broad blue luminescence emission band peaked at 450 nm. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2- ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn(II), complex 1 exhibits a good thermal and acid-proof stability, and can be directly carbonized at 1000 °C under argon atmosphere into a new microporous carbon material C1000. The gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1a and microporous carbon C1000 have been studied by N2 and CO2 sorption measurements.

elements.content: We report the synthesis of a new ultrastable MOF with furan-functionalized pores, ZnL·5H2O (1), which can stabilize up to 450 °C and remain stable in HCl solution (pH = 1) up to a month. Direct carbonization of 1 under argon atmosphere at 1000 °C generates porous carbon C1000; both complex 1 and C1000 have a rather good CO2 adsorption capacity. At 273 K, the uptake of complex 1 and C1000 under 1 bar reaches 81.8 cm3 g−1 (16.1 wt %) and 64.8 cm3 g−1 (12.7 wt %), respectively. In addition, complex 1 exhibits an interesting photoluminescence.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a family of porous crystalline materials assembled from metal centers/clusters and organic linkers. The recent decade has witnessed a continuous and fast development in the research on MOFs due to their structural versatility and chemical nature tunability. In particular, owing to their exceptionally high surface areas and adjustable pore structures, MOFs have been extensively noted as promising porous materials that can be effectively tailored to specific functional applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, proton conductors, luminescent sensing materials, and drug delivery. More recently, considerable attention has been paid to the task-specific design and pore surface decoration of MOFs with intriguing architectures and multifunctional properties. In comparison with other types of porous materials, such as zeolites and activated carbons, MOFs display many advantages (i.e. high surface area and pore volume, structural tunability and functionalization, and easy synthesis). However, the inherent drawbacks of relatively low thermal and chemical stability for most MOFs restrict their large-scale applications in practice and development in industries. Thermally, MOFs usually can stabilize up to 250 °C, beyond which the framework starts to collapse or decompose. Otherwise, most MOFs are sensitive to moisture, especially in an acidic or basic medium; MOFs are poorly chemically resistant. Up to date, only a few MOFs show high thermal and chemical stabilities. Therefore, the design and synthesis of MOFs with ultrahigh thermal and chemical stability is still challengeable for chemists, but indispensible for practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a family of porous crystalline materials assembled from metal centers/clusters and organic linkers. The recent decade has witnessed a continuous and fast development in the research on MOFs due to their structural versatility and chemical nature tunability. In particular, owing to their exceptionally high surface areas and adjustable pore structures, MOFs have been extensively noted as promising porous materials that can be effectively tailored to specific functional applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, proton conductors, luminescent sensing materials, and drug delivery. More recently, considerable attention has been paid to the task-specific design and pore surface decoration of MOFs with intriguing architectures and multifunctional properties. In comparison with other types of porous materials, such as zeolites and activated carbons, MOFs display many advantages (i.e. high surface area and pore volume, structural tunability and functionalization, and easy synthesis). However, the inherent drawbacks of relatively low thermal and chemical stability for most MOFs restrict their large-scale applications in practice and development in industries. Thermally, MOFs usually can stabilize up to 250 °C, beyond which the framework starts to collapse or decompose. Otherwise, most MOFs are sensitive to moisture, especially in an acidic or basic medium; MOFs are poorly chemically resistant. Up to date, only a few MOFs show high thermal and chemical stabilities. Therefore, the design and synthesis of MOFs with ultrahigh thermal and chemical stability is still challengeable for chemists, but indispensible for practical applications.

elements.content: Very recently, MOFs with high thermal stability have been demonstrated as attractive templates to prepare various porous carbon materials, applied extensively in odor absorbers, batteries, supercapacitors, and full cells. By this pathway, the carbonization of carbon sources (such as furfuryl alcohol) occurs in the pores of MOFs. However, owing to the large carbon content of origin components in MOFs, it may not be always necessary for introducing additional carbon sources as additives, and MOFs can be carbonized directly in an inert atmosphere to form microporous or nanoporous carbons. Compared with the traditional methods (i.e. activation of precursors and carbonization of polymer aerogels) for preparing porous carbon materials, the above synthetic pathways using MOFs can produce uniform porous carbons with high surface areas and high adsorption capacity, and therefore promote the practical applications of such materials in H2 storage, CO2 uptake, and supercapacitors.

However, owing to the large carbon content of origin components in MOFs, it may not be always necessary for introducing additional carbon sources as additives, and MOFs can be carbonized directly in an inert atmosphere to form microporous or nanoporous carbons. Compared with the traditional methods (i.e. activation of precursors and carbonization of polymer aerogels) for preparing porous carbon materials, the above synthetic pathways using MOFs can produce uniform porous carbons with high surface areas and high adsorption capacity, and therefore promote the practical applications of such materials in H2 storage, CO2 uptake, and supercapacitors.

elements.content: It is well-known that the instability of MOFs is mostly caused by the change of metal coordination geometry through loss of coordinated solvent molecules during desolvation. One possible solution to this problem is to use multidentate chelating ligands. In [Zn2(bptc)]·4H2O, the bptc4– ligand forms two very stable tridentate chelating synthons with metal ions via two carboxylate O donors and one N donor, and the donor atoms on the ligand occupy all the coordination sites of Zn­(II). As a result, the open framework of [Zn2(bptc)] can be stable up to 450 °C, and only decomposes in strong acid (e.g., pH < 2) or strong base (pH > 14) media. Our own recent work has focused on the use of polytopic heterofunctional ligands to construct unusual coordination polymers or MOFs. Herein, we report a new framework material [Zn­(L)]·5H2O (1) based on Zn­(II) bound to anionic 4′-furyl-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine-4,4″-dicarboxylate (L2–, see ). In this multidenate heterofunctional ligand, there is one very stable N-N-N tridentate chelating synthon with metal ions, while the two carboxylates can easily compete with solvent molecules to fulfill the metal coordination geometry, and the furyl moiety can serve as a noncoordination functional group dangling in the pores of the framework. As expected, the resulting framework material shows ultrahigh stability (up to 450 °C), especially in strong acidic aqueous media (e.g. aqueous HCl with pH = 1), and reversibly absorbs gas molecules into the framework pores. Interestingly, direct carbonization of 1 under argon atmosphere at 1000 °C generates porous carbon C1000. Compared with 1, although C1000 has a lower surface area, it shows a good CO2 uptake capacity.

elements.content: All of the regents not specifically listed below were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. The potassium salt of 4′-furyl-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid (K2L, ) was prepared according to the procedure described previously. The elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on KBr pellets 4000–500 cm–1 using a PECO (U.S.A.) Spectrum One FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a TGA/DSC 1 STARe system at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, from 35 to 1000 °C under N2 atmosphere. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Miniflex2 diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Gas adsorption measurements were performed on the ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 System. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a Hitachi SU8010. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were taken on an FEI Tecnai F20. Raman spectra were obtained using a Renishaw UV-1000 Photon Design spectrometer at 532 nm excitation focused through at 100 × microscope objective for a total interrogation spot size of ∼1 μm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All of the regents not specifically listed below were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. The potassium salt of 4'-furyl-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine-4,4"-dicarboxylic acid (K2L, ) was prepared according to the procedure described previously. The elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on KBr pellets 4000-500 cm-1 using a PECO (U.S.A.) Spectrum One FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a TGA/DSC 1 STARe system at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, from 35 to 1000 °C under N2 atmosphere. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Miniflex2 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Gas adsorption measurements were performed on the ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 System. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a Hitachi SU8010. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were taken on an FEI Tecnai F20. Raman spectra were obtained using a Renishaw UV-1000 Photon Design spectrometer at 532 nm excitation focused through at 100 × microscope objective for a total interrogation spot size of ~1 μm.

elements.content: In a typical run, Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), K2L (0.047 g, 0.1 mmol) and CH3COOH (2.0 mL) were stirred in H2O (10.0 mL) and sealed in a stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon-liner. The reaction mixture was heated at 180 °C for 120 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature, resulting in brown crystals of 1, which were washed several times with H2O, filtered and dried. The yield of the reaction was 42%, based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 (C21H21N3O10Zn): C 46.64, H 3.91, N 7.77; found: C 47.08, H 3.88, N 7.62; Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 3410 (br), 1608(s), 1551(s),1482­(m), 1456­(w) 1363(s), 1237­(m), 1012­(m), 871 (m), 778 (m), 700 (s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [ZnL]⋅5H2O (1)

In a typical run, Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), K2L (0.047 g, 0.1 mmol) and CH3COOH (2.0 mL) were stirred in H2O (10.0 mL) and sealed in a stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon-liner. The reaction mixture was heated at 180 °C for 120 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature, resulting in brown crystals of 1, which were washed several times with H2O, filtered and dried. The yield of the reaction was 42%, based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 (C21H21N3O10Zn): C 46.64, H 3.91, N 7.77; found: C 47.08, H 3.88, N 7.62; Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 3410 (br), 1608(s), 1551(s),1482(m), 1456(w) 1363(s), 1237(m), 1012(m), 871 (m), 778 (m), 700 (s).

elements.content: The carbonization of as-synthesized 1 was performed under a argon flow at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 up to 1000 °C, kept at this temperature for 8 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The obtained carbon materials were herein designated as C1000.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of C1000 

The carbonization of as-synthesized 1 was performed under a argon flow at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 up to 1000 °C, kept at this temperature for 8 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The obtained carbon materials were herein designated as C1000.

elements.content: Diffraction data of 1 were collected at 293 K on a SuperNova Atlas diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods, and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL-97 program package. All ordered non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined with a riding model. One of two noncoordination furan rings was modulated in disorder along the axis defined by the C–C bond between furan ring and the central pyridine ring. The highly disordered guest solvents could not be well modeled in the refinement, so they were removed by using the SQUEEZE option in PLATON. The diffuse electron density in the pore cavities, calculated from SQUEEZE, was at 709 electrons per unit cell, corresponding to ca. 5H2O per [ZnL], which has been confirmed by elemental analysis and TGA. Details for structural analysis are summarized in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction data of 1 were collected at 293 K on a SuperNova Atlas diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods, and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL-97 program package. All ordered non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined with a riding model. One of two noncoordination furan rings was modulated in disorder along the axis defined by the C-C bond between furan ring and the central pyridine ring. The highly disordered guest solvents could not be well modeled in the refinement, so they were removed by using the SQUEEZE option in PLATON. The diffuse electron density in the pore cavities, calculated from SQUEEZE, was at 709 electrons per unit cell, corresponding to ca. 5H2O per [ZnL], which has been confirmed by elemental analysis and TGA. Details for structural analysis are summarized in Table S1.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O with K2L using CH3COOH to adjust pH = 2 at 180 °C for 72 h affords a pure phase of brown block crystals of 1 (42% yield). A series of experimental parameters, such as the reaction time, temperature, solvent, and pH, were tested for the formation of the resultant MOF. It was found that in all these factors the pH value (adjusted with acetic acid) plays the most important role in affecting the quality of the final crystallized product. The pH value must be adjusted to 2.0 to obtain pure crystalline products.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

The hydrothermal reaction of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O with K2L using CH3COOH to adjust pH = 2 at 180 °C for 72 h affords a pure phase of brown block crystals of 1 (42% yield). A series of experimental parameters, such as the reaction time, temperature, solvent, and pH, were tested for the formation of the resultant MOF. It was found that in all these factors the pH value (adjusted with acetic acid) plays the most important role in affecting the quality of the final crystallized product. The pH value must be adjusted to 2.0 to obtain pure crystalline products.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pnaa space group, with the asymmetric unit consisting of two Zn2+ ions and two ligands L2–, and it shows a new type of 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) framework constructed from Zn­(II) ions and anionic ligands L2–. Each Zn(1) or Zn(2) ion is coordinated by a tridendate chelating array comprising three pyridyl N-donors, all from the same terpyridyl moiety of a L2– ligand (a). The remaining two coordination sites of the Zn(1) ion are completed by two carboxylate oxygen atoms, O­(7A) and O­(9B), from two adjacent L2– ligands, affording a distorted trigonal bipyramidal configuration with the O­(7A)–Zn(1)–O­(9B) bond angle of 124.09(16)o and the two coordination planes (O­(7A)–Zn1–O­(9B)–N2 and N1–Zn1–N3 in a) almost perpendicular to each other (dihedral angle 83.991(2)°). The Zn(2) ion is further bound to three carboxylate O atoms from two different L2– ligands, giving O­(2C)–Zn(2)–O(3), O­(2C)–Zn(2)–O(4), and O(3)–Zn(2)–O(4) bond angles of 93.87(18), 151.2(2), and 57.38(19)°, respectively, with the two coordination planes (O­(2C)–Zn(2)–O(3)–O(4)–N(5) and N(4)–Zn(2)–N(6) in a) almost perpendicular to each other by symmetry (dihedral angle 89.568(1)°). Therefore, the Zn(2) ion adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Both Zn–N [2.071(4) – 2.145(3) Å)] and Zn–O bond distances [1.957(3) to 2.314(5) Å, see Table S2] are in the normal ranges compared to those reported for the Zn–O bond lengths found in MOFs.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. (a) Coordination geometries of Zn­(II) and linking modes of L2– ligands (symmetric modes: A, 1 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 + z; B, 1 – x, −0.5 + y, −0.5 + z; C, 0.5 + x, 0.5 – y, z; D, 1 – x, 0.5 + y, −0.5 + z; E, 1 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 + z; F, −0.5 + x, 0.5 – y, z). (b) Schematic view of the polyhedral cage [Zn(1)­N3O2] with [Zn(2)­N3O3] polyhedra highlighted in green and turquoise, respectively. The purple bold sticks between Zn­(II) centers represent the linkage via pyrindyl-4-carboxylate moieties in L2– ligands). (c and d) Views of the 3D framework, along the b and c axes, respectively (the noncoordination furan rings are highlighted in spacing mode).

elements.content: In 1, there are two crystallographically independent L2– ligands sustaining the 3D framework through different linkages. The first one is almost coplanar, completely parallel to the ab plane, only chelated to the Zn(1) center via the terpyridyl moiety, and links two Zn(2) ions via carboxylate groups along the a axis of the unit cell; the other is only chelated to the Zn(2) center via the terpyridyl moiety, and links two Zn(1) ions via carboxylate groups along the c axis of the unit cell. Such linkages result in the formation of a 3D 4-connected sra -type framework (c and d) with 42.63.8 topology (a and Figure S3), in which both Zn(1) and Zn(2) centers act as a 4-connecting node, while the pyridyl-4-carboxylate moieties in L2– ligands essentially serve as the linkers between Zn(1) and Zn(2) nodes (b). Interestingly, seven Zn(1) and seven Zn(2) centers are alternately bonded by 17 pyridyl-4-carboxylate moieties in L2– ligands to form a large irregular polyhedral cage with cavity diameter of ca.10 Å (b and Figure S1). Thus, the overall framework of 1 can also be viewed as the closed packing of the irregular polyhedral cages. Meanwhile, 1 shows interconnected channels along all three crystallographic axes. However, both the irregularly hexagonal channels along the a axis (Figure S2a) and the octagonal channels along the c axis (d) are split and partly blocked by noncoordination furan rings. The approximate dimension of the square channels (c) along the b axis is ca. 8 Å × 8 Å, and is defined by the span of the pyridyl-4-carboxylate linker of the bridging ligands. Upon 2-fold interpenetration, the square channels are divided into two types of smaller rectangular channels. If considering the van der Waals radius of the nearest atoms, at least one type of rectangular channels are too narrow to allow any solvent molecules to pass the channels, which is clearly shown in the space-filling mode of b. However, 1 still possesses an effective 1D channel when viewed along the c axis (c). In fact, the solvent-accessible void for 1 was estimated using the software PLATON to be 29.3% of the unit cell volume, and the porosity of desolvated 1a has been confirmed by the adsorption of N2 and CO2.

elements.content: Remarkably, complex 1 possesses not only open channels decorated with noncoordination furan groups, but also high thermal and acid-proof stability relative to most known MOFs. The thermal stability of 1 has been evaluated in the temperature range 35–1000 °C under an N2 stream (Supporting Information, Figure S5). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss of 16.1% from 35 to 150 °C, corresponding to the release of trapped molecules in pores (calcd 16.6%), followed by a relatively steady plateau until 450 °C, beyond which the framework of 1 starts to decompose. The crystalline phase purity of 1 was confirmed by comparing experimental PXRD patterns with the simulated one from single-crystal data. As shown in a, although some diffraction peaks become weaker along with the increase of acidity, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 remain almost intact upon immersion in aqueous HCl solutions with different pH values from 0.2 to 7 for 5 days, suggesting that no phase transition or framework collapse occurs upon treatments in acidic aqueous solution. However, complex 1 is unstable in basic solutions. To further evaluate the chemical stability of 1 in strong acid solution, as-synthesized samples were soaked in aqueous HCl solution at pH = 1 for different times. Strikingly, the results, as shown in b, indicated that 1 has good acid resistance even after 30 days. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2– ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn­(II), the coordination bonds, as well as the whole framework of 1, become highly resistant to the attack of water and even acid. However, in basic aqueous solutions the strong coordinating ability of hydroxyl ions gradually results in the collapse of framework.

Thermal and Chemical Stabilities of 1 

Remarkably, complex 1 possesses not only open channels decorated with noncoordination furan groups, but also high thermal and acid-proof stability relative to most known MOFs. The thermal stability of 1 has been evaluated in the temperature range 35-1000 °C under an N2 stream (Supporting Information, Figure S5). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss of 16.1% from 35 to 150 °C, corresponding to the release of trapped molecules in pores (calcd 16.6%), followed by a relatively steady plateau until 450 °C, beyond which the framework of 1 starts to decompose. The crystalline phase purity of 1 was confirmed by comparing experimental PXRD patterns with the simulated one from single-crystal data. As shown in a, although some diffraction peaks become weaker along with the increase of acidity, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 remain almost intact upon immersion in aqueous HCl solutions with different pH values from 0.2 to 7 for 5 days, suggesting that no phase transition or framework collapse occurs upon treatments in acidic aqueous solution. However, complex 1 is unstable in basic solutions. To further evaluate the chemical stability of 1 in strong acid solution, as-synthesized samples were soaked in aqueous HCl solution at pH = 1 for different times. Strikingly, the results, as shown in b, indicated that 1 has good acid resistance even after 30 days. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2- ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn(II), the coordination bonds, as well as the whole framework of 1, become highly resistant to the attack of water and even acid. However, in basic aqueous solutions the strong coordinating ability of hydroxyl ions gradually results in the collapse of framework.

elements.content: Luminescent MOFs have been extensively investigated owing to their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent devices, and so on. The luminescent property of 1 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Upon photoexcitation at 370 nm, complex 1 displays a broad blue luminescence emission band peaked at 450 nm (). In comparison to the emission peak at 460 nm (λex = 370 nm) of the salt of ligand K2L, the maximum emission of 1 does not exhibit a significant shift, while, its luminescent strength increases notably. The Zn­(II) ion has a d10 configuration, which is difficult to oxidize or reduce, and as a result, metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) will not occur in emission. Therefore, the luminescent emission band of 1 can be assigned to the intraligand emission, and the luminescent enhancing is attributed to the coordination bonds between the Zn2+ and the ligand, which adjust the conformational rigidity of ligands and cause the decrease of nonradiation transition.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties of 1 

Luminescent MOFs have been extensively investigated owing to their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent devices, and so on. The luminescent property of 1 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Upon photoexcitation at 370 nm, complex 1 displays a broad blue luminescence emission band peaked at 450 nm (). In comparison to the emission peak at 460 nm (λex = 370 nm) of the salt of ligand K2L, the maximum emission of 1 does not exhibit a significant shift, while, its luminescent strength increases notably. The Zn(II) ion has a d10 configuration, which is difficult to oxidize or reduce, and as a result, metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) will not occur in emission. Therefore, the luminescent emission band of 1 can be assigned to the intraligand emission, and the luminescent enhancing is attributed to the coordination bonds between the Zn2+ and the ligand, which adjust the conformational rigidity of ligands and cause the decrease of nonradiation transition.

elements.content: Recently, high thermal and chemical stable MOFs, such as MOF-5, Al-PCP, and ZIF-8, have been extensively roasted in the presence of additional carbon sources (such as furfuryl alcohol) to prepare porous carbons. Hu and co-workers carried out a systematic investigation about the thermal decomposition of MOF-5. Through focusing on the characteristics of decomposed products and study of relative mechanism, they provided significant information on the carbonization of MOFs. Considering the large carbon content, the high thermal stability, and the presence of noncoordination furan rings (an analogue to the additional source in preparing porous carbons), a new type of porous carbon materials (C1000) has been successfully prepared by direct carbonation of 1 in argon atmosphere. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of directly carbonizing 2-fold interpenetrated MOFs to prepare porous carbon materials. The SEM images indicated that the obtained C1000 retained the bulk morphology of 1 (a and b). EDX analysis (c) indicated that all the Zn metal in 1 has been removed after carbonization at 1000 °C. As shown in d, the PXRD pattern of C1000 only displays two broad peaks at 2θ = 25° and 44°, corresponding to carbon (002) and (101) diffraction peaks, respectively. The broad nature of diffraction peaks indicates the amorphous feature of C1000. In order to get a better knowledge of C1000, TEM and Raman spectra characterizations were conducted. As clearly observed in a and b, C1000 has a porous structure, which is consistent with the result of a N2 gas adsorption–desorption isotherm. The high resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image (c) reveals that C1000 possessed lots of nanopores over the entire particle surface with a graphitic structure. This was confirmed by the Raman spectra shown in d. The intensity ratio (IG/ID) of the peaks roughly at 1367 cm–1 (D band) and 1603 cm–1 (G band) is 1.02, which indicates that disordered and graphitic structures were developed in the C1000.
elements.clean_text:
Microporous Carbon C1000 Prepared by Direct Carbonization of 1 

Recently, high thermal and chemical stable MOFs, such as MOF-5, Al-PCP, and ZIF-8, have been extensively roasted in the presence of additional carbon sources (such as furfuryl alcohol) to prepare porous carbons. Hu and co-workers carried out a systematic investigation about the thermal decomposition of MOF-5. Through focusing on the characteristics of decomposed products and study of relative mechanism, they provided significant information on the carbonization of MOFs. Considering the large carbon content, the high thermal stability, and the presence of noncoordination furan rings (an analogue to the additional source in preparing porous carbons), a new type of porous carbon materials (C1000) has been successfully prepared by direct carbonation of 1 in argon atmosphere. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of directly carbonizing 2-fold interpenetrated MOFs to prepare porous carbon materials. The SEM images indicated that the obtained C1000 retained the bulk morphology of 1 (a and b). EDX analysis (c) indicated that all the Zn metal in 1 has been removed after carbonization at 1000 °C. As shown in d, the PXRD pattern of C1000 only displays two broad peaks at 2θ = 25° and 44°, corresponding to carbon (002) and (101) diffraction peaks, respectively. The broad nature of diffraction peaks indicates the amorphous feature of C1000. In order to get a better knowledge of C1000, TEM and Raman spectra characterizations were conducted. As clearly observed in a and b, C1000 has a porous structure, which is consistent with the result of a N2 gas adsorption-desorption isotherm. The high resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image (c) reveals that C1000 possessed lots of nanopores over the entire particle surface with a graphitic structure. This was confirmed by the Raman spectra shown in d. The intensity ratio (IG/ID) of the peaks roughly at 1367 cm-1 (D band) and 1603 cm-1 (G band) is 1.02, which indicates that disordered and graphitic structures were developed in the C1000.

elements.content: The as-synthesized crystals were heated at 120 °C for 24 h under high vacuum to obtain the desolvated sample 1a, and the rigid framework of 1a has been verified by the PXRD pattern (Figure S6). The porosity of desolvated 1a and microporous carbon C1000 has been examined by nitrogen and CO2 absorption experiments. As shown in a, the N2 adsorption of 1a at 77 K shows a reversible type-I adsorption behavior characteristic of microporous material. Based on the N2 isotherm, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface area of 1a are calculated to be 523.6 and 774.7 m2g–1, respectively. Analysis with density functional theory (DFT) from the N2 sorption curve indicates that the size of micropores mainly concentrated around 0.8 nm, which is in accordance with the crystallographic data when van der Waals contact is considered.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Studies of Desolvated 1a and Microporous Carbon C1000 

The as-synthesized crystals were heated at 120 °C for 24 h under high vacuum to obtain the desolvated sample 1a, and the rigid framework of 1a has been verified by the PXRD pattern (Figure S6). The porosity of desolvated 1a and microporous carbon C1000 has been examined by nitrogen and CO2 absorption experiments. As shown in a, the N2 adsorption of 1a at 77 K shows a reversible type-I adsorption behavior characteristic of microporous material. Based on the N2 isotherm, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface area of 1a are calculated to be 523.6 and 774.7 m2g-1, respectively. Analysis with density functional theory (DFT) from the N2 sorption curve indicates that the size of micropores mainly concentrated around 0.8 nm, which is in accordance with the crystallographic data when van der Waals contact is considered.

elements.content: The CO2 sorption isotherms of 1a, measured at 273 and 298 K under ambient pressure, also display type-I adsorption behavior without any hysteresis (b). At 1 bar, 1a shows a relatively high CO2 uptakes of 81.8 cm3g–1 (16.1 wt %) at 273 K and 59.2 cm3g–1 (11.6 wt %) at 298 K. These values can be well compared to those reported for many MOFs structures under similar conditions. It is well documented that open metal sites in MOFs are very beneficial for enhancing the adsorption capacities of gases. It should be noted that 1a does not have any open metal sites. The noncoordination furan rings, which are located on the wall of pores of 1a and can be as functional group with electron rich property, may play a certain degree of contribution to its relatively high CO2 uptake.

elements.content: The typical type-I isotherm of N2 sorption at 77 K for C1000 also exhibits a steep increase in the very low P/P 0 range, suggesting microporsity of the obtained carbon material (a). The BET and Langmuir surface areas of C1000 are calculated to be 362.4 and 505.1 m2 g–1, respectively, slightly lower than those of desolvated 1a. Microporous carbon C1000 still exhibits a certain degree of CO2 adsorption capacity, with uptake of 64.8 cm3 g–1 (12.7 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar. However, a slight hysteresis is observed, in contrast to the completely reversible adsorption for 1a (b). The hysteresis sorption behavior of C1000 may be attributed to the residual N atoms in the carbon material, which derive from N-doped ligand L2– and have a relatively strong interaction with absorbed CO2. Recently, Bai et al. used Co-MOFs as precursors to prepare multiwalled carbon nanotubes with a high BET surface area (400–500 m2 g–1) by direct pyrolysis of MOFs particles, in which the Co-MOFs can provide both carbon sources and metal catalysts for the formation of carbon nanotubes during the carbonization. Compared with the metal doped carbon nanotubes, the metal-free C1000 has a lower BET surface area, while its CO2 adsorption capacity (2.9 mol kg–1) doubled that of CN-1 (1.4 mol kg–1) at 1 bar.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized a new 3D 2-fold interpenetrated metal–organic framework 1. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2– ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn­(II), complex 1 exhibits a good thermal and acid-proof stability, and can be directly carbonized into a new microporous carbon material C1000. Both desolvated 1a and the obtained microporous carbon C1000 show a relatively good CO2 sorption capacity. Further studies on supercapacitor electrodes based on such carbon materials are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized a new 3D 2-fold interpenetrated metal-organic framework 1. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2- ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn(II), complex 1 exhibits a good thermal and acid-proof stability, and can be directly carbonized into a new microporous carbon material C1000. Both desolvated 1a and the obtained microporous carbon C1000 show a relatively good CO2 sorption capacity. Further studies on supercapacitor electrodes based on such carbon materials are underway.

cln_elements.content:
In a typical run, Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), K2L (0.047 g, 0.1 mmol) and CH3COOH (2.0 mL) were stirred in H2O (10.0 mL) and sealed in a stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon-liner. The reaction mixture was heated at 180 °C for 120 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature, resulting in brown crystals of 1, which were washed several times with H2O, filtered and dried. The yield of the reaction was 42%, based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 (C21H21N3O10Zn): C 46.64, H 3.91, N 7.77; found: C 47.08, H 3.88, N 7.62; Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 3410 (br), 1608(s), 1551(s),1482­(m), 1456­(w) 1363(s), 1237­(m), 1012­(m), 871 (m), 778 (m), 700 (s).

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Structural Characterization

The hydrothermal reaction of Zn­(CH3COO)2·2H2O with K2L using CH3COOH to adjust pH = 2 at 180 °C for 72 h affords a pure phase of brown block crystals of 1 (42% yield). A series of experimental parameters, such as the reaction time, temperature, solvent, and pH, were tested for the formation of the resultant MOF. It was found that in all these factors the pH value (adjusted with acetic acid) plays the most important role in affecting the quality of the final crystallized product. The pH value must be adjusted to 2.0 to obtain pure crystalline products.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [ZnL]⋅5H2O (1)

In a typical run, Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), K2L (0.047 g, 0.1 mmol) and CH3COOH (2.0 mL) were stirred in H2O (10.0 mL) and sealed in a stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon-liner. The reaction mixture was heated at 180 °C for 120 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature, resulting in brown crystals of 1, which were washed several times with H2O, filtered and dried. The yield of the reaction was 42%, based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1 (C21H21N3O10Zn): C 46.64, H 3.91, N 7.77; found: C 47.08, H 3.88, N 7.62; Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 3410 (br), 1608(s), 1551(s),1482(m), 1456(w) 1363(s), 1237(m), 1012(m), 871 (m), 778 (m), 700 (s).

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

The hydrothermal reaction of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O with K2L using CH3COOH to adjust pH = 2 at 180 °C for 72 h affords a pure phase of brown block crystals of 1 (42% yield). A series of experimental parameters, such as the reaction time, temperature, solvent, and pH, were tested for the formation of the resultant MOF. It was found that in all these factors the pH value (adjusted with acetic acid) plays the most important role in affecting the quality of the final crystallized product. The pH value must be adjusted to 2.0 to obtain pure crystalline products.

cln_elements.content:
We report the synthesis of a new ultrastable MOF with furan-functionalized pores, ZnL·5H2O (1), which can stabilize up to 450 °C and remain stable in HCl solution (pH = 1) up to a month. Direct carbonization of 1 under argon atmosphere at 1000 °C generates porous carbon C1000; both complex 1 and C1000 have a rather good CO2 adsorption capacity. At 273 K, the uptake of complex 1 and C1000 under 1 bar reaches 81.8 cm3 g−1 (16.1 wt %) and 64.8 cm3 g−1 (12.7 wt %), respectively. In addition, complex 1 exhibits an interesting photoluminescence.

Thermal and Chemical Stabilities of <bold>1</bold>

Remarkably, complex 1 possesses not only open channels decorated with noncoordination furan groups, but also high thermal and acid-proof stability relative to most known MOFs. The thermal stability of 1 has been evaluated in the temperature range 35–1000 °C under an N2 stream (Supporting Information, Figure S5). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits an initial weight loss of 16.1% from 35 to 150 °C, corresponding to the release of trapped molecules in pores (calcd 16.6%), followed by a relatively steady plateau until 450 °C, beyond which the framework of 1 starts to decompose. The crystalline phase purity of 1 was confirmed by comparing experimental PXRD patterns with the simulated one from single-crystal data. As shown in a, although some diffraction peaks become weaker along with the increase of acidity, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 remain almost intact upon immersion in aqueous HCl solutions with different pH values from 0.2 to 7 for 5 days, suggesting that no phase transition or framework collapse occurs upon treatments in acidic aqueous solution. However, complex 1 is unstable in basic solutions. To further evaluate the chemical stability of 1 in strong acid solution, as-synthesized samples were soaked in aqueous HCl solution at pH = 1 for different times. Strikingly, the results, as shown in b, indicated that 1 has good acid resistance even after 30 days. Due to the chelating effect of trepyridyl moieties in L2– ligands and the absence of solvent coordination sites on Zn­(II), the coordination bonds, as well as the whole framework of 1, become highly resistant to the attack of water and even acid. However, in basic aqueous solutions the strong coordinating ability of hydroxyl ions gradually results in the collapse of framework.

Gas Adsorption Studies of Desolvated <bold>1a</bold> and Microporous Carbon <bold>C1000</bold>

The as-synthesized crystals were heated at 120 °C for 24 h under high vacuum to obtain the desolvated sample 1a, and the rigid framework of 1a has been verified by the PXRD pattern (Figure S6). The porosity of desolvated 1a and microporous carbon C1000 has been examined by nitrogen and CO2 absorption experiments. As shown in a, the N2 adsorption of 1a at 77 K shows a reversible type-I adsorption behavior characteristic of microporous material. Based on the N2 isotherm, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface area of 1a are calculated to be 523.6 and 774.7 m2g–1, respectively. Analysis with density functional theory (DFT) from the N2 sorption curve indicates that the size of micropores mainly concentrated around 0.8 nm, which is in accordance with the crystallographic data when van der Waals contact is considered.

The CO2 sorption isotherms of 1a, measured at 273 and 298 K under ambient pressure, also display type-I adsorption behavior without any hysteresis (b). At 1 bar, 1a shows a relatively high CO2 uptakes of 81.8 cm3g–1 (16.1 wt %) at 273 K and 59.2 cm3g–1 (11.6 wt %) at 298 K. These values can be well compared to those reported for many MOFs structures under similar conditions. It is well documented that open metal sites in MOFs are very beneficial for enhancing the adsorption capacities of gases. It should be noted that 1a does not have any open metal sites. The noncoordination furan rings, which are located on the wall of pores of 1a and can be as functional group with electron rich property, may play a certain degree of contribution to its relatively high CO2 uptake.

The typical type-I isotherm of N2 sorption at 77 K for C1000 also exhibits a steep increase in the very low P/P 0 range, suggesting microporsity of the obtained carbon material (a). The BET and Langmuir surface areas of C1000 are calculated to be 362.4 and 505.1 m2 g–1, respectively, slightly lower than those of desolvated 1a. Microporous carbon C1000 still exhibits a certain degree of CO2 adsorption capacity, with uptake of 64.8 cm3 g–1 (12.7 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar. However, a slight hysteresis is observed, in contrast to the completely reversible adsorption for 1a (b). The hysteresis sorption behavior of C1000 may be attributed to the residual N atoms in the carbon material, which derive from N-doped ligand L2– and have a relatively strong interaction with absorbed CO2. Recently, Bai et al. used Co-MOFs as precursors to prepare multiwalled carbon nanotubes with a high BET surface area (400–500 m2 g–1) by direct pyrolysis of MOFs particles, in which the Co-MOFs can provide both carbon sources and metal catalysts for the formation of carbon nanotubes during the carbonization. Compared with the metal doped carbon nanotubes, the metal-free C1000 has a lower BET surface area, while its CO2 adsorption capacity (2.9 mol kg–1) doubled that of CN-1 (1.4 mol kg–1) at 1 bar.

The porosity of desolvated 1a and microporous carbon C1000 has been examined by nitrogen and CO2 absorption experiments. As shown in a, the N2 adsorption of 1a at 77 K shows a reversible type-I adsorption behavior characteristic of microporous material. Based on the N2 isotherm, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface area of 1a are calculated to be 523.6 and 774.7 m2g-1, respectively. Analysis with density functional theory (DFT) from the N2 sorption curve indicates that the size of micropores mainly concentrated around 0.8 nm, which is in accordance with the crystallographic data when van der Waals contact is considered.

The CO2 sorption isotherms of 1a, measured at 273 and 298 K under ambient pressure, also display type-I adsorption behavior without any hysteresis (b). At 1 bar, 1a shows a relatively high CO2 uptakes of 81.8 cm3g-1 (16.1 wt %) at 273 K and 59.2 cm3g-1 (11.6 wt %) at 298 K. These values can be well compared to those reported for many MOFs structures under similar conditions. It is well documented that open metal sites in MOFs are very beneficial for enhancing the adsorption capacities of gases. It should be noted that 1a does not have any open metal sites. The noncoordination furan rings, which are located on the wall of pores of 1a and can be as functional group with electron rich property, may play a certain degree of contribution to its relatively high CO2 uptake. 

The typical type-I isotherm of N2 sorption at 77 K for C1000 also exhibits a steep increase in the very low P/P 0 range, suggesting microporsity of the obtained carbon material (a). The BET and Langmuir surface areas of C1000 are calculated to be 362.4 and 505.1 m2 g-1, respectively, slightly lower than those of desolvated 1a. Microporous carbon C1000 still exhibits a certain degree of CO2 adsorption capacity, with uptake of 64.8 cm3 g-1 (12.7 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar. However, a slight hysteresis is observed, in contrast to the completely reversible adsorption for 1a (b). The hysteresis sorption behavior of C1000 may be attributed to the residual N atoms in the carbon material, which derive from N-doped ligand L2- and have a relatively strong interaction with absorbed CO2. Recently, Bai et al. used Co-MOFs as precursors to prepare multiwalled carbon nanotubes with a high BET surface area (400-500 m2 g-1) by direct pyrolysis of MOFs particles, in which the Co-MOFs can provide both carbon sources and metal catalysts for the formation of carbon nanotubes during the carbonization. Compared with the metal doped carbon nanotubes, the metal-free C1000 has a lower BET surface area, while its CO2 adsorption capacity (2.9 mol kg-1) doubled that of CN-1 (1.4 mol kg-1) at 1 bar.
